Question: To what extent is there a robust legal or regulatory framework for the protection of personal data in the country?
Existence
What is the nature of the framework?
Option1: A framework exists but lacks full force of law
Option2: A framework exists and has the force of law
Supporting0: 0,1;In the absence of a strong legal framework, are there alternative norms or customs that play this role in the country? If so, please explain how.
Supporting1: 2;Please identify the framework(s) you have assessed (e.g. name of law(s) or regulations)
Supporting2: 0,1;If there are draft laws or regulations not yet in force, but that would provide a more robust framework in future, please provide brief details here.

Question: Elements
Part 1:
The framework includes the right of choice or consent
The framework provides the right to access and correct data
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders
The framework provides rights of redress
Part 2:
Frameworks apply equally to migrants
Frameworks cover the protection of location-related data
Extent
How broadly does this data protection framework apply?
Option0: The framework only applies in a narrow set of situations
Option1: The framework applies widely in one or more sectors
Option2: The framework applies widely across all sectors (including public and private sector)
Option3: The framework applies widely across all sectors and there is strong evidence that it is implemented effectively

Question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing structured data from company registers?
Existence
Are there laws, policies or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
Option1: They are being drafted, or are not yet implemented.
Supporting0: 1;Please provide brief details

Question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations or guidance discuss collection and publication of structured and open data?
Option0: Relevant laws, policies and guidance explicitly create barriers to collecting and publishing structured data
Option1: There is no mention of data in relevant laws, policies or guidance
Option2: Requirements to collect data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance
Option3: Requirements to collect data are set out in binding policy, regulations or law
Option4: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance
Option5: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy or law
Supporting0: 0;Please briefly detail the barriers created (e.g. requirements for paper-based filing only)
Supporting1: 2,3,4,5;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy or guidance

Question: Elements
Part 1: What do the rules or guidance related to structured data cover?
The framework requires collection of data on directors and shareholders
Basic company information, including company name, legal form, status, and registered address
Supporting0: 1;If one or more of the basic company data features is not covered, please list which (e.g. registered address)

Question: Structured data on the shareholders of each company
Regularly updated and structured financial data
Supporting0: 0;(Optional) Is structured company accounting data collected through any other mechanism or agency (e.g. tax offices, operating separately from the company register)?
Supporting1: 1,2;(Optional) Please briefly describe any requirements for firms to file structured data accounts or financial returns (e.g. is structured data filing voluntary or mandatory? Do exemptions exist for small firms?)

Question: Part 2: What other requirements do the rules or guidance set out?
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support publication of open data.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
Extent
How widely do these laws, regulations, policies or guidance apply?
Option0: The laws, policies and guidance assessed cover a limited number of localities or government agencies
Option1: The relevant laws, policies and guidance assessed cover, or are representative of those covering, many localities or government agencies
Option2: The relevant laws, policies and guidance assessed cover the majority of public procurement

Question: To what extent is there a well-resourced open government data initiative in the country?
Elements
There is a leader in place for
To what extent are there effective institutions and processes that deliver data protection in practice?
Existence
Is there an established and effective Data Protection Authority?
Option0: There is no data protection authority
Option1: A Data Protection Authority exists, but has limited independence and powers, or is not currently functioning.
Option2: A Data Protection Authority exists and has powers to oversee data protection, including applying sanctions.
Option3: A Data Protection Authority exists with relevant powers, including powers to sanction, and there is evidence of it using these powers efficiently and effectively in at least some cases.
Option4: A Data Protection Authority exists with relevant powers, including powers to sanction, and there is evidence of it using these powers efficiently and effectively in the majority of cases.
Supporting0: 0;In the absence of a Data Protection Authority, are there other institutions that individuals and communities seeking protection of their privacy rights can turn to?

Question: Are there are civil society organisations, law firms or other non-government stakeholders who support individuals and communities to exercise their data protection rights?
Option1: There is very limited access to support
Option2: There is one or more organisation working to provide support to individuals or communities on data protection issues in the country, but they are not well established, have limited resources, and/or face considerable barriers in engaging with government
Option3: There are established and effective organisations with a track record in taking forward advocacy or cases to protect individual or community data protection rights
Option4: There are established and effective organisations with a track record in taking forward advocacy or cases to protect individual or community data protection rights, and access to this kind of support is available to all groups within society
